DIV2.HEAD: From Venice the 20 of Iune 1621.
DIV2.P: HEre are 3 Ambassadors arriued being sent from Bethlem Gabor, but as yet haue not audience by the Signiorie, what was the contents of their commis∣sion is yet vnknowne, but expect tobe informed therof by the next Letters.

DIV2.HEAD: From Constantinople the 28 of Iune.
DIV2.P: The great and mightie Lord, with all his so great forces is vpon his march toward Poland, which whole Ringdome he is wholy bent to spoyle, & fully resolued to make tributarie vnto the Turkish Empire: and with∣al meanes this Sommer to make way through the hart of the Kingdome, euen to the strong & mightie Cittie Cracaw, further it is obserued that the Cossacks and Polanders, left and forsaken Podolia and are retired back vnto Poland.

DIV2.HEAD: From Vienna in Austira the 21 of Iune.
DIV2.P: The Emperour haueing beene at Mariensel, where he had beene at his deuotion with the Archduke Charles, is now returned; in his passage through Mewstadt, the youg Prince of Anhalt being prisoner: haueing desired audience, & withall entreating for mercie at the hands of his Imperiall Maiestie, whereof he was vtterlie de∣nied, yet was he the very same night visited by the Arch duke Charles, and was by him possessed of much com∣fort.

The English Gentelmen that was com to the Em∣perour, and had giuen his Imperiall maiestie to vnder∣stand, that the Lord Ambassador Digbie was vnder way: is by his maiestie sent back againe to the said Am∣bassador, for to aduise him to take his way towards Prague, and there to tarrie for his Imperiall maiestie: for he ment to betake himselfe theitherwards vpon the 5 of Iuly: but yet it is supposed as farre as men can con∣ceiue that, that his iorney may be deferred to some o∣ther time, because of ye Hungarian affayres where mat∣tecs doe not fall out according to the desire of the Em∣perour: especially considering ye the Count of Bucquoy could not by no meanes preuent nor hinder ye entrance of the 4000 men into Newhewsel which were sent thi∣ther for their succor and ayde: it is generally thought, & that upon some good ground ye if the besieged can hould out but for ye space of thrée weekes longer, which with∣out doubt they can, for they want neither men, meat, munition, nor mony, but are sufficientlie prouided for of all necessahies, that Bucpuoy of necessitie shalbe for∣ced with all his leger to breake vp, and to returne back some other way, for Bethelem Gabor doth fortifie him∣selfe extraordinarilie strong with Turks, and Tarta∣rians being now wholy readie to march vp with ye same for the reliefe of Newhewsell.

DIV2.HEAD: From Vienna the 8 of Iuly.
DIV2.P: Whereat the count de Bucquoy who haueing to lit∣tle purpose layen so long afore the Cittie Newhewsel in Hungaria, resoluing now to take a more serious view of the Cittie, to the end they might the better fit them∣selues in bringing their cannons to ye most conuenient places for battering, made out of their campe by night in tending with the breake of day, in the twilight to effect their purposes, & to that end as is Bucquoy: Maxemil∣ian of Lightenser the Lord of Diepenbuch and others to the number of 40 speciall men of note went out, but whereas they went out 40 ther returned not the halfe as they went, for the Hungarians who slippe not away their advantage) liuing then in the woods next by, com∣passed them so about, that they went very neere to the taken or slaying of them all, and it was very narroulie that Bucquoy himselfe of escaped, but how soeuer it fell out that he esaped yet there remayned dead 18 and di∣vers of the rest sorelie hurt.

DIV2.HEAD: From Lipswick the 18 of Iulv.
DIV2.P: In Silesia vpon the Emperour his side it stands not well but very slightlie for ye cruell and bloodie execution at Prague the 21 of Iune of thrée Earls and Lord: 7 knights the rest Councellors and Cittizens to the num∣ber of 47 in all, hath bread such distast discord & dissen∣tion euen vnto desperation of any hope of good mild or gentill dealings at the hands of the blood thyrstie Em∣perour, so that the said states of Silesia take on great store of men for their owne and counteries defence. In like manner the Marquisse of iegere Dorp lay there with his Souldiers who had strongly beset the Cittie Newes, & the Earldome of Glets, besides that he was fallen into Bohemia wigh 10000 braue old Souldiers.

In respect whereof the Corronel Sassen was com∣manded that he should with his 6 cornets or companies of horsemen breake vp from Prague, and so march vp to Koningsgets, otherwise Kinggrets: likewise the Cor∣ronell of wallenstegn was ready with certaines com∣panies of foote to follow for the resistaunce of them of Iagerens dorp so much as possible they could.

It is also signified that the young Graue of Thurin who holds him by the Marquisse of Iagerens Drop be-4000 men strong, is fallen into the Dukedomes of Re∣schen and Toppau, and therein taken the best passages and strongly beset the same. The Graue of Mansfield lies with his whole leger vppon the fronties of Bohe∣mia most in the vpper Palatinate.

DIV2.HEAD: The Letter which Graue Mansfeld wrote to Bethelem Ga∣bor King of Hungaria whereby he shewed his Christian Resollution.
DIV2.P: Most Illustrious Prince mighty and puissant King most gratious Lord, and howsoeuer my gracious King and Lord, the great and bitter misfortune crossing his Maiestie in Bohemia, happening so much against him to the excessiue griefe and hart sore not of me alone, but also of all his true and faithfull subiects, yet on the con∣trarie, all true Christian Professors of the Gospel re∣ioyce no lesse to see and behold your Maiesties not one∣lie great loue manifested, but also your most heroicall and magnanimous hart, wherewith you affect both the Kingdome of Bohemia, and all the confederate Lands: and not onely so, but therewith all your great zeale for the planttacion of the Gospell, euen the true Religion and speciall care for pretecting all sincere honest men from the tyrannie of the Pope, and the crueltie of the Spanish yoke.

As for me I haue alwayes from the beginning vnto this present, to the vttermost of my power furthered, and wil not be backward in going on according to my dutie for the performance of my promise withall fidelitie, to his Kinglie Maiestie of Bohemia in the doing of al that shalbe profitable seruiceable, to my gratious King and Lord, as also to the whole Kingdome to my vtmost en∣deauours: In consideration whereof I haue alwayes
kept vnder obedience of his Maiesty Cittis the Tobor and Wittenkaw and against all onsets of the eneime, I haue constantlie and manfully defended and pretect∣ed the same, I tooke Tackhaw by Gods permission out of the hands and power of his enimies, and haue now for the defence thereof beset it with men of warre: the Cloyster Doepel aright neast of murtherers, I haue disabled, Slecthen wald with there owne consent, I haue taken in euen as they of Ellenbogh did by Creits in which Cittie the inhabitants besides the Souldiers therein haue hitherto truelie, and faithfully, as became resolute souldiers, held and carried themselues, caused ye enemie to retire, renewing their promises constantly and faithfully to mayntaine the Christian Religion: & their beloued natiue Countite, & therevpon to hasard both life & goods, whicher also I haue with the first con∣veniencie resolued to betake my selfe, Moreouer & let all the bordering Citties Townes and Castels, which the enemie may set on, or besiege, be prouided for of all manner of prouision, I entend also by Gods grace, and that ere long to attempt some notable matter of waight and in portaunce, for & meditate continually, and be∣thinke me night and day, how & by what meanes this Tyrannicall Austria, and this heauy & cruell Spanish yoke might be shaken off, and expulsed and this King∣dome brought againe to its former estate, and so holpen to its desired peace. For which cause I could not con∣ceale from your Kinglie Maiestie, how that Spayne hath other sufficient imployments, otherwayes, as also that the Duke of Sauoy my most gratious Lord, with the mightie Duke of Venice, wilbe imployed in some notable seruices, the Swithers haue held hard by the King of France for helpe, for the recouerie of veltolia the States of Hoolland wilbe armed both by sea & Land it were vame to say more of the Austrian councel tiran∣nicall persecution, or of the two well knowne Spanish Inquisitions, I am also very busie in the taken on of men, hoping within a few weeks to haue 15 thousand thoren men of warre in readines, but considering that for the better expedition of ye warrs, I haue great neede of 2000 horsmen, my earnest suite therefore to your Maiestie is that you wilbe pleased and that withall possible speed to furnish me with the aforesayd number of 200 Hungarian horsemen, if it be possible, and I as soone as I shallbe so furnished, will spare neither la∣bor nor paines for the erformaunce of that seruice, that may serue for the furderaunce of the Christiun religion, and the welfare of the Kingdome of Bohemia, for my fidelite wherein your Maiestie shall in nothing doubt: but without the said number of horse I shall not be a∣ble to performe that seruice I would, which therefore I will expect with the first opertunitie: hopeing withall that your Maieste is and willbe an vpholder as of the Christian Religion, so also of this our natiue Countrie manifesing your selfe to be are that wil, not to suffer your selfe to be deceiued by the bloody Papists, nor yet to be drawne by their deceitfull pretences, to a faise faith∣lesse and vniust peace, the rather considiring that their cruell and abominable tyronies deceitfullnesse and per∣iuries are euery where too too manifest, which many doe dailie féele and vndergoe, and heartily bewaile with sighs and teeres: herewith concluding I will pray vnto allmightie God for your Maiesties prosperous raigne, the ouerenmming of your enemies and so ear∣nestly beséeching that he will be your protector I shall with longing expect your certaine resolution and an∣swere

CLOSER.SIGNED: Meane time resting your Kingly Maiesties al∣waies most dutifull obedient Earnesss Graue of Mansfield, Marquis of Niewcastle, Lord of Thaldrung and cheife gouernor and Mashall of his Maiestie of Bohemia, his men of warre.

DIV2.P: The rest of the prisoners in Orague are pardonned & are discharged and let goe: Duke Luke onelie expected: and the commissionners of the Emperours were vpon their departure into Morauia towards Brm, not vnlike as is generally thought, but that some there also may be brought to the fleshbank vnder the hands of the like Butchers.

THe Duke of Bauaria hath called togeither ye Stats of the Land vpon the Ens, for to acknowledg him their Lords and gouernors, or otherwise in case they will not, then to pay him 2800000 florins, which he hath on the of the Emperour disbursted and layd out.

DIV2.HEAD: From Cullen the 19 of Iuly 1621.
DIV2.P: The next wéeke shall the new Spaniards vnder the commaund of the Mark-graue of Ansbach his brother, be mustered and then shal remayne in the Palatinate.

In Berghlandt 6 companies of foote march higher towards Niewborghs quarters, about Papen Muts for to hinder them of the fort or Schonce, that they may not cut any more of the willowes for the fortifiing of their Sconce.

The Horsemen of the enemies, which were hereto∣fore brought into Butphen prisoners, are proclaimed for prise and are set vppon a ransome, their horses armor and weapons were by the sound of a Trumpet sould, Wherevpon Graue Hendrick Vanden Bergh a Span∣ish generall, hath written that he meant, that sith they on their side had as yet shewed no manner of hostilitie, that he thought it should be also on their side: so that the prisoners vpon his promise of contenting them, as for their ransome might be sent againe: wherevpon the pri∣soners were discharged & afterward departed to Zut∣phen.
Newes from Brussels certifie that the Earle of Bucquoy is slaine.

DIV1.P: Printed at Altmore by M H, Iuly 29. 1621.
